title: Jeremy Hunt accused of "cover up" after 708,000 NHS patient records were lost
text:
Jeremy Hunt accused of "cover up" after 708,000 NHS patient records were lost The Health Secretary told MPs in July "some correspondence" had gone missing. Now he admits it was 708,000 confidential records   Share   Comments By Jason Beattie 17:12, 27 FEB 2017 News Jeremy Hunt only said some correspondence was lost, not 700,000 records (Photo: Birmingham Mail)   Share   Comments Get politics updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email Jeremy Hunt stands accused of a “cover up” after admitting that more than 700,000 NHS medical records were lost.
The Health Secretary said the confidential correspondence between GPs and hospitals were placed in storage between 2011 and 2016.
Despite being made aware of the scandal in March last year Mr Hunt only told MPs in July when he said “some correspondence” had not arrived.
Only when summoned to the Commons yesterday, did the Health Secretary reveal that hundreds of thousands of records had gone missing.
He said the private firm charged with delivering the records, NHS Shared Business Services, had held 708,000 documents in a warehouse.
Mr Hunt admitted this was a “completely unacceptable lapse in efficiency” but said so far there was no evidence patients had been put at risk.
Jeremy Hunt admits the blunder was 'unacceptable' (Photo: Reuters) He told MPs the majority of the correspondence had now been passed on and Shared Business Services was no longer providing the service.
The Health Secretary said a review of 705,500 documents found no patients had been put at risk but the Department of Health was still examining 2,500 records relating to patients in the East Midlands, the South West and north east London.
Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth said patients deserved an apology for the “catastrophic breach of data protection.”
“Over half a million patients’ data including blood tests results, cancer screening results, biopsy results, even correspondence relating to cases of child protection - all undelivered.
“They were languishing in a warehouse on the Secretary of State’s watch. It’s an absolute scandal,” he said.
Shadow Health Secretary Jon Ashworth said it was a "scandal" (Photo: Getty) Mr Ashworth said Mr Hunt “stands accused of a cover up.”
He added: “Two months into 2017 and the Health Secretary lurches from one crisis to another. Hospitals overcrowded, waiting lists out of control.
“He can’t deliver the investment our NHS needs, he can’t deliver a social care solution, he can’t deliver patient safety and now he can’t even deliver the post.”
Mr Hunt denied he had covered up the blunder, saying he was advised to keep it quiet to avoid GP surgeries being “overwhelmed” by inquiries form patients.
“As soon as we judged it was possible to do so, we informed this House, we informed the public and we stayed absolutely true to our commitment, both to patient safety and to transparency,” he said.
